description: {"blocks":[{"key":"eiuma","text":"Bovine coronavirus (BCoV) has spilled over to many species, including humans, where the host range variant coronavirus OC43 is endemic. Balance of the opposing activities of the surface spike (S) and hemagglutinin esterase (HE) glycoproteins control virion avidity which is critical for interspecies transmission and host adaptation.  Here, 78 genomes were sequenced directly from clinical samples collected between 2013 and 2022 from cattle in 12 states, primarily in the Midwestern U.S.  Relatively little genetic diversity was observed, with genomes having \u003e98% nucleotide identity. Eleven isolates collected between 2020 and 2022 from four states (Nebraska, Colorado, California, and Wisconsin) contained a 12-nucleotide insertion in the receptor-binding domain (RBD) of the HE gene identical to one recently reported in China, and a single genome from Nebraska collected in 2020 contained a novel 12-nucleotide deletion in the HE gene RBD. Isogenic HE proteins containing either the insertion or deletion in the HE RBD maintained esterase activity and the ability to bind bovine submaxillary mucin, a substrate enriched in the receptor 9-O-acetylated-sialic acid, despite modeling that predicted structural changes in the HE R3 loop critical for receptor binding.  The emergence of BCoV with structural variants in the RBD raises the possibility of further interspecies transmission.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":1143,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
disclaimer: {"blocks":[{"key":"32tn4","text":"•The findings and conclusions in this presentation are those of the authors and should not be construed to represent any official USDA or U.S. Government determination or policy.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"e9i4d","text":"•Mention of trade names or commercial products in this presentation is solely for the purpose of providing specific information and does not imply recommendation or endorsement by the USDA.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f70ft","text":"•USDA is an equal opportunity provider and employer","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

manuscript_citation: Recent emergence of bovine coronavirus variants with mutations in the hemagglutinin-esterase receptor binding domain in U.S. cattle (submitted)

status.info: We use this protocol and it's working

The STDOUT is found at the beginning of the file and the alignments follow the STDOUT","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"blsjo","text":" All .afa_out files were split in a text editor into two separate .out and .afa files for downstream analysis.  ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"2tdch","text":"The input FASTA file headers contain description information; this header information should be stripped out to facilitate readable, compact leaf names/identifiers. Use the following command to strip out the description text.  ","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"d4eug","text":" thethe","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":1,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"3m6n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dcgkr","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":11,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"bi4p0","text":"DESCRIPTION","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":5,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"8mtk4","text":"MAFFT is a multiple sequence alignment program for unix-like operating systems. It offers a range of multiple alignment methods.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7v53","text":"
","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":26,"offset":0,"style":"bold"}],"key":"16mgk","text":"Accuracy-oriented methods:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2eh","text":"• L-INS-i (probably most accurate; recommended for <200 sequences; iterative refinement method incorporating local pairwise alignment information):","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"318sk","text":"

is a how-to, which describes how RAxML  should best be used for a simple real-world biological analysis, given an example alignment named ex_al"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2oqbc","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"3gicv","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"drvh9","text":"Now, if you want to run a full analysis, i.e., BS and ML search type:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"dvlhf","text":"
","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"8jlab","text":"raxmlHPC -­f a ­-x 12345 -­p 12345 ­-# 100 ­m GTRGAMMA ­-s ex_al -­n TEST","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"7vdn2","text":"
","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"26eup","text":"This will first conduct a BS search and once that is done a search for the best–scoring ML tree.","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"e4l15","text":"Such a program run will return the bootstrapped trees (RAxML_bootstrap.TEST), the best scoring ML tree(RAxML_bestTree.TEST), and the BS support values drawn on the best-scoring tree as node labels (RAxML_bipartitions.TEST) as well as, more correctly since support values refer to branches as branch labels (RAxML_bipartitionsBranchLabels.TEST).","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"6s11l","text":"
","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2sred","text":"Finally, note that by increasing the number of BS replicates via  -# you will also make the ML thorough since for ML optimization every 5th BS tree is used as a starting point to","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"19fiq","text":"for ML trees.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"10":{"type":"file","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"3238B8C002F311EDBD48E332B5A7CD53","height":0,"id":268182,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"","original_name":"RAxML_bestTree.192_Genomes_Final_6_14_22.jtt_100.globalpair.SEQID_Only.T8.N2000","placeholder":"https://www.protocols.io/img/extensions/N2000.png","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/if6yjrq6.N2000","type":5,"width":0}},"11":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"64C110C002F911EDBD48E332B5A7CD53","url":"https://itol.embl.de/tree/162219193109347161657293088"}},"12":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"084DC4A002F911EDBD48E332B5A7CD53","url":"https://itol.embl.de/"}},"13":{"type":"image","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"E95B94D0039F11EDA22EF55BB1735D02","height":1503,"id":277404,"is_video":false,"legend":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":9,"offset":318}],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"f69cl","text":"RAxML tree of 192 bovine coronavirus genomes. Bootstrap support values are proportional to the line thickness of the branches. Isolates with HE deletions are denoted with a filled red square while the single isolate with an HE insertion is denoted with a filled blue square.  Tree metrics are best investigated in the IToL tree.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{"0":{"data":{"guid":"F7FEE04003A011EDA22EF55BB1735D02","url":"https://itol.embl.de/tree/162219193109347161657293088"},"mutability":"MUTABLE","type":"link"}}},"mime":"image/png","original_name":"hnEPVpuE7ZfeZxYfs7R0mg.png","placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/iq68jrq6.jpg","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/iq66jrq6.jpg","type":1,"webp_placeholder":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/iq67jrq6.webp","webp_source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/iq65jrq6.webp","width":550}},"14":{"type":"file","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"8B2B5670039F11EDA22EF55BB1735D02","height":0,"id":268650,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"application/pdf","original_name":"RaXML tree of 192 livestock coronavirus genomes.pdf","placeholder":"https://www.protocols.io/img/extensions/pdf.png","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/igmkjrq6.pdf","type":5,"width":0}},"2":{"type":"notes","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"blocks":[{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"cfj8j","text":"Thus,  if  you  run  RAxML  with  32  instead  of  1  thread  this  does  not  mean  that  it  will  automatically become 32 times faster, it may actually even become slower. As I already mentioned, the parallel efficiency,  that  is,  with  how  many  threads/cores  you  can  still  execute  it  efficiently  in  parallel depends on the alignment length, or to be more precise on the number of distinct patterns in your alignment. ","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"1n1jk","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"c0g8j","text":"This  number  is  printed  by  RAxML  to  the  terminal  and  into  the  RAxML_info.runID file"	","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"af7g4","text":"and look like this:","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"2eljs","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"caop4","text":"Alignment has 70 distinct alignment patterns	","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[],"key":"32dk1","text":"","type":"unstyled"},{"data":{},"depth":0,"entityRanges":[],"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":50,"offset":18,"style":"bold"}],"key":"1jvfp","text":"As a rule of thumb I'd use one core/thread per 500 DNA site patterns, i.e., if you have less, than it's probably better to just use the sequential version. Single-gene DNA alignments with around 1000 sites can be analyzed with 2 or at most 4 threads. Thus, the more patterns your alignment has, the more threads/cores you can use efficiently.","type":"unstyled"}],"entityMap":{}}},"3":{"type":"link","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"186444E012AD11ED94F43F097D922BA0","url":"https://cme.h-its.org/exelixis/resource/download/NewManual.pdf"}},"4":{"type":"command","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"id":10536,"name":"nohup raxmlHPC -T 8 -f a -x 12345 -p 12345 -N 2000 -m GTRGAMMA -s 192_Genomes_Final_6_14_22.jtt_100.globalpair.SEQID_Only.afa -n 192_Genomes_Final_6_14_22.jtt_100.globalpair.SEQID_Only.T8.N2000 >  192_Genomes_Final_6_14_22.jtt_100.globalpair.SEQID_Only.T8.N2000.out &","os_name":null,"os_version":null,"command_name":"","description":"Run raxmlHPC command using nohup on 'nix platform to protect from premature job termination in case of remote connection loss ... and run in background with & at end of command line. Perform a 2000 boostrap search followed by a search for the best-scoring maximum likelihood tree.

-T 8  ( use 8 threads)
-f a  
-x 12345
-p 12345
-m GTRGAMMA
-N 2000","can_edit":1,"guid":"62621BB0009411EDB05D1566C34381CA"}},"5":{"type":"file","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"178D7B5002F311EDBD48E332B5A7CD53","height":0,"id":268177,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"","original_name":"RAxML_bootstrap.192_Genomes_Final_6_14_22.jtt_100.globalpair.SEQID_Only.T8.N2000","placeholder":"https://www.protocols.io/img/extensions/N2000.png","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/if6tjrq6.N2000","type":5,"width":0}},"6":{"type":"file","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"218F209002F311EDBD48E332B5A7CD53","height":0,"id":268178,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"","original_name":"192_Genomes_Final_6_14_22.jtt_100.globalpair.SEQID_Only.T8.N2000.out","placeholder":"https://www.protocols.io/img/extensions/out.png","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/if6ujrq6.out","type":5,"width":0}},"7":{"type":"file","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"27427A5002F311EDBD48E332B5A7CD53","height":0,"id":268179,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"","original_name":"RAxML_info.192_Genomes_Final_6_14_22.jtt_100.globalpair.SEQID_Only.T8.N2000","placeholder":"https://www.protocols.io/img/extensions/N2000.png","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/if6vjrq6.N2000","type":5,"width":0}},"8":{"type":"file","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"2C1697A002F311EDBD48E332B5A7CD53","height":0,"id":268180,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"","original_name":"RAxML_bipartitionsBranchLabels.192_Genomes_Final_6_14_22.jtt_100.globalpair.SEQID_Only.T8.N2000","placeholder":"https://www.protocols.io/img/extensions/N2000.png","raw_source":"","source":"https://s3.amazonaws.com/protocols-files/files/if6wjrq6.N2000","type":5,"width":0}},"9":{"type":"file","mutability":"MUTABLE","data":{"guid":"2F824B5002F311EDBD48E332B5A7CD53","height":0,"id":268181,"is_video":false,"legend":"","mime":"","original_name":"RAxML_bipartitions.192_Genomes_Final_6_14_22.jtt_100.glo
